content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Answer the following questions about hydrogen and oxygen gases. (a) A particle-level representation of <math alttext="O 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the balloon below on the left. The balloon on the right contains the same volume of <math alttext="H 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> at the same temperature and pressure. In the balloon on the right, draw a representation of <math alttext="H 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> with the appropriate number and distribution of particles.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Answer the following questions about hydrogen and oxygen gases. (a) A particle-level representation of <math alttext="O 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the balloon below on the left. The balloon on the right contains the same volume of <math alttext="H 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> at the same temperature and pressure. In the balloon on the right, draw a representation of <math alttext="H 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> with the appropriate number and distribution of particles.

(b) The graph below shows the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution for <math alttext="H 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. On the same graph, draw the distribution curve for <math alttext="O 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> at the same temperature.

<math alttext="2 H 2 O, liquid, reacts to produce 2 H 2, gas, plus O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> To generate the <math alttext="H 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>(</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.05em"></mspace><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></math> and the <math alttext="O 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>(</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.05em"></mspace><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></math>, a student performs electrolysis of water, represented by the equation above. The student collects the gases in tubes and then adjusts the position of one of them so that the water levels inside and outside of the tube are the same, as shown in the following diagram. (c) Is the gas collected in tube <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="H 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> or <math alttext="O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.
(d) What volume should the student report for the gas in tube <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>?

(e) Is <math alttext="H 2, gas " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> produced at the anode or cathode? Justify your answer in terms of oxidation numbers.

(f) The atmospheric pressure in the lab was <math alttext="0.989 atmosphere " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.989</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="22.0 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>22.0</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The vapor pressure of water at <math alttext="22.0 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>22.0</mn><mo>°</mo><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="0.026 atmosphere" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.026</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Calculate the pressure of dry gas in tube <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(g) The value of <math alttext="E naught " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>E</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the electrolysis of water is <math alttext="negative 1.23 volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1.23</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. In a second trial of the experiment, the power source was replaced with a voltmeter. Would the volume of hydrogen gas produced be greater than, less than, or equal to the volume produced in the original experiment? Justify your answer.

(h) The student considers the reverse reaction and proposes a mechanism with a single, elementary step as shown below.<math alttext="2 H 2, gas, plus O 2, gas, react to produce 2 H 2 O, liquid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.255em"></mspace><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>(</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.05em"></mspace><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.05em"></mspace><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>(</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.05em"></mspace><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.05em"></mspace><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>(</mo></mrow><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></math>Explain, in terms of particle collisions, why this mechanism is unlikely to be correct.

skill.text: 2.D: Make observations or collect data from representations of laboratory setups or results, while attending to precision where appropriate.
